I.  THE PROPOSAL  
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Xinjiang  Integrated  Urban  Development 
Project.1 The project will improve urban infrastructure facilities and the environment in the cities 
of Kelamayi and Kuitun in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region (XUAR), which will contribute 
to  sustainable  economic  growth  and  improve  the  quality  of  life  for  about  340,000  urban 
residents in the two project cities.2  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
2.  The development of XUAR, one of the poorest and most remote regions in the northwest 
with a large ethnic minority population of Uygur (46% of the total population) and other minority 
ethnic groups (15%), is one of the PRC’s top priorities.3 XUAR is facing serious urbanization 
challenges and remains poor in terms of economic growth. Water availability is a critical concern 
for the fragile ecology, which is predominantly a desert territory characterized by strong winds, 
low rainfall, and high evaporation rates. Infrastructure improvement and provision of basic urban 
services are needed to facilitate environmentally sustainable economic growth—essential to 
improving urban living conditions. 
 
3.  Recognizing  the  need  for  greater  national  support,  the  Government  of  the  PRC 
inaugurated  a  twinning  scheme  whereby  assistance  from  other  provinces  will  be  used  to 
strengthen  the  capacity  in  XUAR  and  improve  local  living  standards.  Nineteen  nominated 
provinces and/or municipalities are providing financial contributions since 2011 and will continue  
to  2020.  The  domestic  support  complements  the  growing  strategic  urban  development 
partnership of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region 
Government (XUARG), along with efforts of other international development partners.4 ADB is 
currently involved in three ongoing urban development projects in the region.5 The proposed 
project will be the fourth ADB-financed urban development project in XUAR. 
 
4.  The project will help XUAR address a common and major urban development constraint 
by enhancing water availability through strengthening wastewater reuse and improving water 
management in two medium-sized cities—Kelamayi and Kuitun.6 Both cities, which are located

6  While Kelamayi is economically important due to the presence of oil, the regional and local governments want to 
create a more diversified economy. Kuitun is on a strategic transportation route (the Old Silk Road) linking the PRC

about by economic modernization.

2 
northwest of the region’s capital (Urumqi)—Kelamayi 350 kilometers (km) away and Kuitun 220 
km are severely water-stressed and have a very harsh climate, with sub-zero temperatures from 
November to March. Annual precipitation in Kelamayi is about 100 millimeters (mm) and in 
Kuitun  about  189  mm.  The  water  management  problems  created  by  lack  of  rainfall  are 
compounded by high evaporation rates averaging over 2,000 mm per annum. The project aims 
to help promote balanced and environment-friendly urbanization, improve living conditions in the 
two  cities,  and  play  a  demonstration  role  for  cities  with  similar  geographic  and  climatic 
conditions in XUAR and elsewhere.  
 
5.  The project aims to adopt an integrated approach to infrastructure development and 
environmental  improvement.  Both  project  cities  have  prepared  integrated  economic 
development plans; subprojects were selected in accordance with priorities identified in the 
plans, with improved water management as a common objective for most of the proposed 
investment.  Municipal  infrastructure  investment,  particularly  focused  on  improved  water 
resources conservation and management which is considered critical to enable sustainable 
development of the two cities. 
 
6.  The  overarching  justification  for  the  ADB  intervention  is  to  demonstrate  how 
improvements in water management can facilitate sustainable economic urban development, 
even in cities with an adjacent desert location, and arid and unfavorable climate for water 
resources management. The project will address two priority water-related issues that feature 
prominently in the local city development plans. In Kelamayi, the major project theme is to 
improve wastewater management to facilitate wastewater reuse as a substitute for freshwater in 
the irrigation of urban green space. In Kuitun, the main theme is river rehabilitation to enhance 
flood  protection  standards,  while  creating  a much-improved urban  environment  to  promote 
economic growth and improve the living conditions of local residents. During project preparation, 
the  design  of  the  Kuitun  components  was  adjusted  to  include  environmental  sanitation 
improvements  targeting  a  particularly  deprived  part  of  the  project  area  and  significantly 
improving  the  inclusiveness  of  the  project  design. 7  In  each  city,  water  management 
improvements  will  demonstrate  the  benefits  to  be  obtained  from  active  nonrevenue  water 
(NRW) management and optimized water distribution networks. In addition to improved water 
management,  existing  arterial  and  smaller  roads  need  to  be  connected  to  ensure  optimal 
development  of  the  town  in  west  Kelamayi.  Inter-  and  intra-road  network  improvement  in 
Kelamayi and Kuitun is important given their proximity to Tacheng, which has one of the largest 
land ports for trade with the Central Asian republics. The development strategies of Kelamayi 
and  Kuitun  focus  on  their  potential  role  in  and  contribution  to  the  Central  Asia  Regional 
Economic Cooperation Program (footnote 6).            
 
7.  Fit with ADB strategy. The project supports environmentally sustainable and inclusive 
economic growth, which is a key priority of ADB’s Strategy 2020.8 By helping foster inclusive 
growth and promote environmental sustainability, the project aligns with ADB’s PRC country 
partnership strategy, 2011–2015,9 which supports the government’s strategic goal of building an 
economically developed society. The project will remove infrastructure constraints, address 
environmental  concerns,  promote  sustainable  economic  growth,  and  support  policy  and 
institutional reforms in Kelamayi and Kuitun. It also conforms to (i) ADB’s Water Operational

3 
Plan,10 particularly  in  terms  of  the  green  and  competitive  cities  agenda,  as  the  project 
encourages water conservation, including wastewater reuse, and NRW reduction; and (ii) ADB’s 
Urban Operational Plan, which fosters competitive, green, and inclusive cities.11 The project is 
consistent with the PRC’s Twelfth Five-Year Plan (2011–2015), which promotes environment-
friendly and resource-efficient urban development, and supports the development of the western 
region. It is consistent with the national economic policy to create more balanced growth as a 
countermeasure to potential large population shifts exacerbating the management of rural–
urban migration brought about by economic modernization. 
 
8.  Continuity of development initiatives and incorporation of lessons. The project will 
follow the 3R12 principles adopted in the Xinjiang Altay Urban Infrastructure and Environment 
Improvement Project to support development of livable cities with a specific focus on water 
reuse and efficiency. The project is envisaged to play a demonstration role for similar cities 
facing water constraints. The project design incorporates lessons from previous ADB-financed 
urban development projects, particularly the three ongoing Xinjiang projects (footnote 5) in the 
PRC and the ADB Special Evaluation Study on Water Policy and Related Operations.13 In 
particular, the project will strengthen support for capacity development starting at the early stage 
of  project  preparation,  with  special  focus  on  (i)  improving  awareness  of  ADB  policy  and 
procedural  requirements  to  facilitate  smooth  implementation  and  timely  compliance,  and  
(ii) strengthening long-term sustainability of the project-built facilities. 
 
9.  Innovative  features.  Special  project  features  include  (i)  support  for  sustainable 
economic  development  in  the  project  cities  with  particular  emphasis  on  improved  water 
management; (ii) demonstration of best practices in the use of wetland storage for wastewater 
reuse and water management improvements; (iii) focus on reducing NRW and improving water 
conservation; (iv)  an  extensive  institutional  capacity  building  program for  the  implementing 
agencies  and  for  future  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  units  to  strengthen  operating 
efficiency and project sustainability; and (v) implementation of climate-friendly development 
practices.14 In particular, the reuse of treated wastewater in Kelamayi will diversify the city’s 
water sources and allow the use of increasingly scarce potable water for only essential domestic 
purposes. The project will contribute to the cities’ target of achieving the status of “model water-
saving cities” by 2018.15  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be improved living conditions and environmental sustainability in the 
cities of Kelamayi and Kuitun. The outcome will be improved urban management and services, 
including upgraded water supply, roads, and flood control in the project cities.

4 
C.  Outputs 
11.  The  project  will  take  a  multisector  approach  to  urban  development  where  water 
availability is the critical constraint to economic development and improved living conditions. 
The project has three outputs. 
 
12.  Output 1: Improvement of Kelamayi’s urban infrastructure. Output 1 will have five 
components: (i) upgrading of the Nanjiao wastewater treatment plant by adding new wastewater 
reclamation  facilities  with  treatment  capacity  of  100,000  cubic  meters  (m3)  per  day; 
(ii) construction of the Jiugongli wetland16 with a surface area of 13.31 square kilometers (kms), 
an average depth of 2 meters, and adequate water volume to receive treated effluent from the 
Nanjiao wastewater treatment plant; (iii) construction of 31.1 km of wastewater reuse pipelines 
to supply reuse water from the wetland for urban forestry and landscaping; (iv) construction of 
11.267  km  of  new  urban  roads;  and  (v)  improvement  of  water  management  including 
rehabilitation  of  7.9  km  of  water  supply  pipelines  and  establishment  of  an  effective  NRW 
management capacity.  
 
13.  Output 2: Improvement of Kuitun’s urban infrastructure. Output 2 will have two 
components: (i) rehabilitation of flood discharge ditches and channels,17 with total length of 
24.72 km together with the auxiliary facilities needed to meet a protection standard of a 1- in 50-
year flood; planting of 200,400 trees covering 83.2 hectares; and construction of related roads 
to provide access and ecological protection, and improve the urban visual environment; and 
(ii) improvement of water management including rehabilitation of 9.43 km of water supply pipes 
and significantly improved NRW management capacity.  
 
14.  Output  3:  Project  management  and  capacity  building.  The  project  will  include 
intensive project management and implementation training for the Xinjiang project management 
office (XPMO) and city project management offices (PMOs), capacity development assistance 
for other concerned agencies,18 and recruitment and management of the project implementation 
consultants.

million of project cost including contingencies. The government has provided ADB with (i) the

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
19.  The project will directly benefit about 340,000 people in Kelamayi and Kuitun. It will 
improve  the  cities’  infrastructure  facilities  and  urban  environment  by  building  new  urban 
infrastructure facilities and enhancing water resources management. Net environmental benefits 
will be gained from broad improvements in the urban environments including the creation of new 
ecological resources, improved wastewater management with effluent reuse, and increased 
resilience to flood events. The reuse of wastewater will be primarily for urban forestry and 
landscaping  (greening)  to  avoid  the  use  of  freshwater  resources  (to  be  used  for  more 
economically productive purposes).   
 
A.  Technical 
20.  All project outputs are designed taking into account local circumstances, topography, 
and climate (arid desert conditions with long harsh winters), and in accordance with relevant 
PRC  design  guidelines  and  local  regulations.  The  process  selected  for  the  enhanced 
wastewater  treatment  is  technically  proven  and  suitable  for  the  local  climate.  The  river 
rehabilitation work in Kuitun will greatly improve the resilience of the city to the potential effects

7 
of climate change, while making significant enhancements to the urban environment. Wherever 
possible, the project designs have incorporated 3R approaches and energy efficiency.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
21.  Economic  analysis, 20  including  least-cost  analysis,  benefit–cost  analysis,  and 
assessments of tariffs and affordability, was conducted for all subcomponents. The least-cost 
analysis confirms the selection of technologies for individual subcomponents. The benefit–cost 
analysis considered direct impacts on beneficiaries, as well as the social value of water savings 
and  changes  in  greenhouse  gas  emissions.  The  overall  project  and  its  components  are 
economically viable with the economic internal rate of return for each component in excess of 
17.1%,  and  overall  project  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  25.5%,  which  exceed  the 
economic opportunity cost of capital of 12%. The sensitivity analysis considered a variety of 
adverse conditions including standard risks such as price shocks or project delays, as well as 
risks that are specific to local conditions such as a failure to achieve growth forecasts. The 
sensitivity  analysis  confirms that  the  economic  performance for  each component  is  robust 
except the water management subcomponent in Kelamayi, which is sensitive to implementation 
delays and the resulting achievement of project benefits. Measures to mitigate this risk are 
included in the project design.  
 
22.  The financial analysis for revenue-generating components was based on key financial 
ratios describing risk and profitability. It evaluated the viability of the proposed investments by 
comparing their financial internal rates of return with the weighted average cost of capital. The 
financial analysis21 and related sensitivity analysis found the project components financially 
viable provided that recommended tariff and capacity-building measures are implemented. The 
financial viability of the Kuitun NRW component is especially dependent on these measures. 
 
23.  Financial  sustainability  analyses  were  completed  for  the  Kelamayi  urban  road 
construction and the Kuitun river rehabilitation components. Counterpart funding requirements, 
debt service costs, and recurrent project O&M costs were compared with forecast revenues and 
expenditures in both cities. The proposed funds flow arrangement for the project is consistent 
with the ongoing ADB projects in Xinjiang and use proven domestic disbursement procedures. A 
financial management assessment concludes that the “with-mitigation” risk is low to medium. 
Required risk mitigation measures are incorporated into institutional development plans within 
the PAM.  
 
C.  Governance 
24.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the XUARG and the municipal governments. The procurement capacity assessment22 of 
the XPMO and city PMOs concludes that the procedural arrangements in place are adequate to 
facilitate full compliance with ADB procurement guidelines. The specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 19).

D.  Poverty and Social 
25.  The project is expected to create positive social benefits through improvements to urban 
ecology,  infrastructure,  and  living  conditions.  The  project  will  directly  benefit  an  estimated 
340,000 people, about 8%–10% are poor. Project construction will create 5,195 direct and 8,312 
indirect  jobs,  while  the  operations  phase  will  create  104  direct  and  73  indirect  jobs.  The 
municipal  governments have  committed to  prioritize  the  employment  of  vulnerable  groups, 
including the poor, women, and ethnic minorities. The implementing agencies will ensure that all 
PRC labor laws and core labor standards are followed. Details on specific measures to ensure 
the poverty and social benefits are in the social development action plan included in the PAM.23 
The social development action plan will facilitate continued consultation and participation of 
communities  in  the  project  area,  and  ensure  that  the  needs  of  the  poor  households  are 
considered. 
 
26.  The project has several design features to reinforce the positive benefits of improved 
access and mobility, public health, and livability in the cities. The provision of public toilets and 
awareness programs on road safety, water conservation, and a public hearing process for water 
tariff reforms will help to ensure that the positive benefits of the infrastructure will be sustainable.  
 
27.  Gender  benefits.  The  project  is  categorized  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming. 
Stakeholder consultations found that women in both cities strongly support the project, believing 
that it will improve their quality of life, address public health risks, and create jobs and income 
opportunities. A gender action plan was prepared to ensure gender benefits accrue in key areas 
of employment, decision-making, participation, and access. Specific actions in the plan include 
employment and training for women during construction and operation; consultation with women 
on  design  and  location  of  public  toilets  and  community-based  waste  collection  and 
management; and outreach, awareness-building, and targets for women's participation in water 
tariff reform. The plan will (i) enhance women’s participation in project activities; (ii) provide 
gender  sensitivity  training  to  PMO  and  implementing  agency  staff;  (iii) ensure  that  project 
decision-making bodies and capacity-building activities are balanced in terms of the gender of 
participants; and (iv) include appropriate gender targets, indicators, and gender-disaggregated 
data for project monitoring and evaluation.24 
 
E.  Safeguards 
28.  Environment  (category  B).  An  initial  environmental  examination  including  the 
environmental management plan25 was prepared following ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009), and posted on the ADB website in February 2013. The project will have significant 
environmental  benefits,  mainly  by  contributing  to  more  sustainable  water  resources 
management. Project construction does have potential impacts on the environment, but these 
are of a temporary nature and covered by stringent site management and procedural provisions 
in the plan, as well as by the loan assurances. The Kelamayi wetland site cleanup has particular 
requirements in the plan for an independent environment site assessment prior to awarding of 
civil works contracts. Capacity building in wetland management, integrated pest management, 
carbon sequestration silviculture, water conservation, and NRW management will help O&M 
units ensure environmental sustainability of project operations.   
 
                                                
23 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
24  Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
25  Initial Environmental Examination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
29.  Involuntary resettlement (category A). Based on the impact of land acquisition and 
resettlement, the Kuitun municipal government has prepared a resettlement plan for the Kuitun 
components. Based on the preliminary impact survey, 2,178 mu26 of state-owned land will be 
acquired. This includes 532 mu27 of cultivable land owned by a state-owned farm and will impact 
19 households and 66 farm employees. In Kuitun, demolition of 31,781 square meters (m2) of 
housing will affect 157 households with 600 residents. Another 4,236 m2 of structures will be 
demolished affecting 56 shops and 127 people. About seven enterprises with 37 workers will be 
affected and 4,546 m2 of structures will be demolished. In total, 830 people will be affected by 
the project. The Kelamayi municipal government prepared one resettlement plan and two due 
diligence reports28 for the Kelamayi urban infrastructure output, for which 15,815 mu of state-
owned land will be acquired affecting one state-owned enterprise and two private enterprises 
with no affected population. Land acquisition will have no impacts on their production and 
operation. The resettlement planning and implementation approach is designed to ensure that 
affected persons will be better off or at least not worse off as a result of the project.29 Copies of 
the resettlement plans in local language were sent to local offices to be easily accessible to the 
affected persons.30 The resettlement plans were disclosed to affected persons in local language 
in February 2013 and the resettlement information booklets were distributed and posted on the 
ADB website on February 2013. A grievance redress mechanism is in place.  
 
30.  Indigenous peoples (category B). Ethnic minorities constitute 7% of the population in 
Kuitun and 25% in Kelamayi. Although the urban communities are ethnically mixed, some 
aspects such as cultural, religious, and linguistic differences are maintained. All households in 
urban areas will benefit from the new infrastructure. Most of the ethnic minority population will 
not be adversely affected by the project, except for 37 individuals of 12 households who will be 
impacted  by  house  demolition,  and  6  households  with  11  residents  who  will  lose  their 
commercial stores in Kuitun. Ethnic minority development plans were prepared and endorsed by 
the Kelamayi and Kuitun municipal governments.31 The plans focus on measures to facilitate 
the inclusion of ethnic minorities in all project activities, and ensure that their customs and 
beliefs will be respected throughout project implementation. Appropriate livelihood restoration 
measures associated with resettlement are incorporated in the resettlement plans. The ethnic 
minority development plans were disclosed in March 2013 to ethnic minorities in the areas 
targeted by the project. Monitoring and reporting arrangements for all these safeguards are 
included in the PAM and the project agreement. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
31.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 5 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.32

plans are not required for these.

IV.  ASSURANCES 
32.  The government and the XUARG have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. The government and the XUARG have agreed with ADB on 
certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan and project agreements.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$200,000,000 to the People’s Republic of China for the Xinjiang Integrated Urban Development 
Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance 
with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 26 years, 
including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.
